page.title: Agostinho Neto, São Tomé and Príncipe

revision.comment: clarifying that the underworld had many names in both languages in first sentence
standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes

revision.text:
{{see also|Fee and dividend|Carbon price}}
{{Infobox organization | name = Citizens' Climate Lobby | abbreviation = CCL | logo = Logo_for_Citizens_Climate_Lobby_2015.png | type = [[Advocacy group]] | focus = [[Carbon fee and dividend]] | established = {{start date and age|paren=yes|2007}} | founder = Marshall Saunders | area_served = Global | key_people = {{Plainlist| * [[George Shultz]] * [[James Hansen]] * [[Bob Inglis]] * [[Katharine Hayhoe]] * [[Sam Daley-Harris]] * [[Daniel Kammen]] }} | num_members = > 80,000 (400 local groups) | homepage = {{url|citizensclimatelobby.org|CitizensClimateLobby.org}} }} '''Citizens' Climate Lobby''' ('''CCL''') is an international [[grassroots]] environmental group that trains and supports volunteers to build relationships with their elected representatives in order to influence [[climate policy]].<ref name="Bornstein">{{cite news|last=Bornstein|first=David|title=Lobbying for the greater good|accessdate=14 November 2013|date=29 March 2013|url=http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/05/29/lobbying-for-the-greater-good/?_r=0|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref> The CCL is a registered [[501(c)(4)]] with approximately $300 thousand in revenue in the [[United States]] in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.guidestar.org/FinDocuments/2015/263/521/2015-263521896-0d50e4c2-9O.pdf|title=CITIZENS CLIMATE LOBBY Form 990 2015|last=Internal Revenue Service|first=|date=|website=Guidestar|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Operating since 2007, the goal of CCL is to build political support across party lines to put a [[Carbon price|price on carbon]], specifically a revenue neutral [[carbon fee and dividend]] (CF&D) at the national level. CCL is supported by notable climate scientists [[James Hansen]], [[Katharine Hayhoe]], and [[Daniel Kammen]].<ref name = "Bornstein"/> CCL's advisory board also includes former Secretary of State [[George P. Shultz]], former US Representative [[Bob Inglis]], actor [[Don Cheadle]], and [[RESULTS (citizen lobby)|RESULTS]] founder [[Sam Daley-Harris]].
Founded in the United States, CCL has groups in Australia, Bangladesh, Brazil, Burundi, Cameroon, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Côte d'Ivoire, France, Gambia, Germany, Ghana, Iceland, India, Italy, Kenya, Mexico, Nepal, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Nigeria, Panama, the Philippines, Poland, Portugal, Qatar, Romania, Serbia, Scotland, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Tanzania, the Ukraine, and the United Kingdom.
== Introduction == The Citizens' Climate Lobby is a non-partisan organization with members throughout the [[United States]], [[Canada]] and other countries, which advocates for effective [[climate legislation]]. Its key purposes are listed as creating a political will for a sustainable climate, while empowering individuals to exercise their personal and political power. With the international/US headquarters in [[Coronado, California|Coronado]], [[California]], and a Canadian national office in [[Greater Sudbury|Sudbury]], [[Ontario]],<ref name ="CCL_Canada">{{cite web|title=Citizens' Climate Lobby Canada|url=http://www.citizensclimatelobby.ca/|accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref> Citizens' Climate Lobby is composed of local volunteer groups who [[Lobbying|lobby]] their elected representatives and work through local outreach and media. Their goal is to cut [[greenhouse gas]] emissions and promote a transition to a [[renewable energy]] economy through a [[market (economics)|market]]-based approach: a revenue neutral '[[carbon fee and dividend]]' approach to pricing carbon pollution from fossil fuels, and simultaneously ending subsidies to [[fossil fuel]] companies.<ref name="Citizens"/> In the United States, using a market-based approach by putting a price on carbon is gaining support from both [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]].<ref name = "Bornstein"/><ref name="republican_case">{{cite web|title=Ruckelshaus, William D., Thomas, Lee M., Reilly, William K. and Whitmann, Christine Todd, A Republican case for Climate Action|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=3 February 2014|date=1 August 2013|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/02/opinion/a-republican-case-for-climate-action.html?_r=1& }}</ref><ref name="inglis">{{cite web|title=Changing the Dialogue on Energy and Climate, Bob Inglis at TEDx Jacksonville|accessdate=3 February 2014|date=10 December 2013|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FUmcnxIQU24 }}</ref><ref name="sheldon_whitehouse">{{cite web|title=Time To Wake Up: Carbon Fee Options by Senator Sheldon Whitehouse|accessdate=3 February 2014|date=27 June 2013|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5_SugBBCURs|}}</ref> CCL believes that a revenue neutral carbon fee and dividend is a bipartisian solution that would effectively address carbon emissions, while not relying on a complex regulation approach.
== History == The Citizens' Climate lobby originated in the United States in 2007 after founder Marshall Saunders recognized the need for progressive climate legislation. Saunders, a successful businessman turned philanthropist, internationally recognized for his work in [[micro loans|micro-credit]], became increasingly concerned about [[climate change]]. Saunders increasingly recognized that while it was necessary for individuals to change their own behavior in the face of climate change, it would never be enough; the time had come for Congress to discontinue subsidizing the [[Fossil fuel#Industry|fossil fuel industry]]. With ever-rising energy production and increased use Saunders believed effective legislation was necessary to cut carbon emissions, by putting a price on carbon.<ref name="Citizens">{{cite web|title=Citizens Climate Lobby, www.citizensclimatelobby.org|url=http://www.citizensclimatelobby.org/|accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref>
Saunders coordinated his efforts to establish Citizens' Climate Lobby with RESULTS, an organization committed to helping volunteer organizations seeking legislative changes to become more effective.<ref name = "Bornstein"/> Groups of volunteers organized by electoral districts could work through local media and elected officials to build public support and political will for change. Citizens' Climate Lobby established its primary, interconnected goals – to achieve legislation at the federal level that would effectively mitigate climate change, to create widespread political will for a sustainable climate, and to empower citizens to better exercise their own political and personal will. United States leadership is widely seen as critical in international emissions reduction efforts, and particularly in carbon pricing, as this would encourage other countries to follow suit with similar legislation.<ref name="Citizens" />
The Citizens' Climate Lobby held its first annual conference in 2009 in Washington D.C., bringing together representatives from around the United States as well as several Canadians. These Canadians subsequently led the establishment of the organization within Canada in 2011, with the first chapter emerging in Sudbury, Ontario.<ref name ="CCL_Canada"/>
Since the initial development of Citizens' Climate Lobby, the group has rapidly grown and spread, from 3 local groups in 2007 to 327 groups in May 2016. They are located throughout the United States and Canada,<ref name ="CCL_Canada"/> and more recently branching out to other countries including [[Sweden]],<ref name="CCL-Sweden">{{cite web|title=CCL-Sweden, www.cclsverige.se |url=http://www.cclsverige.se|accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref> [[Bangladesh]]<ref name="CCL-Bangladesh">{{cite web|title=CCL-Bangladesh |url=https://plus.google.com/+CitizensclimatelobbyOrg/posts|accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref> (both starting in 2013), Australia, Germany, India, Nepal, Panama, United Kingdom, Burundi, Brazil, Cameroon, Chile, France, Kenya, Iceland, Italy, Netherlands, New Zealand, Nigeria, Qatar, Poland, Romania, Portugal, Serbia, Scotland, Switzerland and the Ukraine.<ref name="Citizens" />
Volunteers in local chapters meet monthly for teleconference lectures by climate experts and communication with other groups, to discuss coordinated actions to be undertaken by members, to practice skills involved in lobbying politicians and dealing with media, and to plan local outreach. These activities support the ongoing goals of the organization and contribute to progress toward effective carbon pricing legislation.<ref name="Citizens" />
== Proposed US legislation== Citizens' Climate Lobby proposes national legislation that would reduce US greenhouse gas emissions by placing a fee on [[carbon dioxide]] ({{co2}}) or equivalent gases. The fee would be levied against all fossil fuels at their point of entry into the economy. The revenue that would be collected would be 100% returned as a monthly or annual payment to every American household. This would protect low and middle class Americans from the rising consumer costs associated with the carbon fee. This idea is known as a [[carbon fee and dividend]].
CCL's proposal would start the fee at US $15 per [[ton]] of [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|{{co2}} equivalent]] (3/4 of a penny per pound) and rise $10 per ton each year (1/2 of a penny per pound). The fee would continue to rise until total US {{co2}} equivalent emissions have been reduced to 10% of US {{co2}} equivalent emissions in 1990. To protect US businesses from competition from other countries that do not have carbon pricing mechanisms, a border adjustment would be enacted. Similar to the [[Montreal Protocol]], goods coming from countries without a carbon price would be subjected to a fee at the border. Goods leaving the US for sale in a country without a carbon price would be reimbursed that fee at the border. In addition, all existing subsidies of fossil fuels, including tax credits, would be phased out over the 5 years following enactment.<ref name="proposed_legislation">{{cite web|title=Proposed Carbon Fee and Dividend Legislation|url=http://citizensclimatelobby.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Carbon-Fee-and-Dividend-April-2014.pdf|accessdate=25 September 2014}}</ref>
On September 1, 2016 [[California State Legislature]] passed a measure that urges the United States Congress to enact a tax on carbon-based fossil fuels. The proposal is revenue-neutral, with all money collected going to the bottom 2/3 of American households. So while the resolution is framed as a tax, it is in fact a carbon fee and dividend scheme.<ref name="ajr-43">{{cite web | title = AJR-43 Greenhouse gases: climate change | date = 1 September 2016 | website = California Legislative Information | url = https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201520160AJR43 | access-date = September 12, 2016 }}</ref>
===Model policy in Canada === The [[Canadian province]] of [[British Columbia]] enacted a revenue-neutral carbon tax in 2008. The [[British Columbia carbon tax]] enabled so called "carbon funded tax cuts" because the revenue, instead of being returned as a dividend, is used to offset corporate and personal income taxes. In 2015, a review of British Columbia's emissions found that they had fallen 16% since 2008, while economic activity outperformed the rest of Canada.<ref name="ThinkProgress">{{cite news|last1=Fragroso|first1=Alejandro Davila|title=British Columbia's Carbon Tax Has Been So Successful That Businesses Want To Increase It|url=https://thinkprogress.org/british-columbias-carbon-tax-has-been-so-successful-that-businesses-want-to-increase-it-7a245cde7dc4#.b6n3eajst|accessdate=25 October 2016|work=[[ThinkProgress]]|publisher=[[Center for American Progress]]|date=31 March 2016}}</ref> The policy has been called "popular across the political spectrum" and been considered a model for policies in other states and countries.<ref name="Vox">{{cite news|last1=Roberts|first1=David|title=The left vs. a carbon tax|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/10/18/13012394/i-732-carbon-tax-washington|accessdate=25 October 2016|work=[[Vox.com]]|agency=Vox|date=18 October 2016}}</ref>
===Proposed measure in Washington=== In 2016, a group called CarbonWA, allied but unaffiliated with the Citizens Climate Lobby, submitted a carbon pricing measure to the [[Washington elections, 2016|ballot]] in the [[State of Washington]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Kramer |first=Becky |date=3 October 2016 |title=Nation's first carbon tax on the ballot in Washington |newspaper=[[The Spokesman-Review]] |url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2016/oct/03/nations-first-carbon-tax-on-the-ballot-in-washingt/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170719163817/http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2016/oct/03/nations-first-carbon-tax-on-the-ballot-in-washingt/ |archive-date=2017-07-19 |access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref> The initiative, known as [[Washington Initiative 732]], would impose a steadily rising fee on emissions of carbon dioxide, and use that revenue to offset the state's [[sales tax]], business tax, and to expand the state's version of the [[earned income tax credit]].<ref name="Vox"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://yeson732.org/plain-language/|title=Carbon Washington {{!}} Our Policy|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-07}}</ref>
==Economic basis for action== Citizens' Climate Lobby advocates putting a price on carbon based on the support of both conservative and liberal economists, including: [[George P. Shultz|George Shultz]], [[Gary Becker]], [[Gregory Mankiw]], [[Art Laffer]], [[Nicholas Stern]], and [[Shi-Ling Hsu]].<ref name="conservative_economists"/>
Shultz was former secretary of state under President Ronald Reagan. Becker is Nobel laureate economist and economics professor at the University of Chicago. Greg Mankiw was Mitt Romney's former economic adviser.<ref name="conservative_economists" /> Nicholas Stern is chair of the [[Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment]] at the [[London School of Economics]] and also chair of the [[Centre for Climate Change Economics and Policy]] (CCCEP) at [[Leeds University]] and [[London School of Economics|LSE]]. Shi-Ling Hsu is the D'Alemberte Professor and Associate Dean for Environmental Programs, [[Florida State University College of Law]].<ref name="florida-state-university-2015">{{cite web | title = College of Law, Florida State University — Deans | date = 2015 | website = College of Law, Florida State University | location = Florida, USA | url = http://www.law.fsu.edu/our-faculty/deans/hsu | access-date = September 11, 2016 }}</ref>
Shultz and Becker support a revenue-neutral carbon tax (where all the revenue collected is paid back to each household in the form a dividend): "We argue for revenue neutrality on the grounds that this tax should be exclusively for the purpose of leveling the playing field, not for financing some other government programs or for expanding the government sector. And revenue neutrality means that it will not have fiscal drag on economic growth."<ref name="conservative_economists">{{cite web | url = http://dailycaller.com/2013/04/08/conservative-economists-write-op-ed-in-support-of-carbon-tax/ | title = Conservative economists write op-ed in support of carbon tax | author = Michael Bastach | date = 8 April 2008 | work = Daily Caller }}</ref>
Economist and law professor Shi-Ling Hsu also supports a revenue-neutral carbon tax. In his book ''The Case for a Carbon Tax, Getting Past our Hangups to Effective Climate Policy'' and in his talks, he explains the economics of carbon pricing and why he believes that putting a price on carbon in the form of a carbon tax is more effective and efficient than cap and trade or command and control style legislation.<ref name=Hsu_Book_Review>{{cite web |title= Book Review: The Case for a Carbon Tax |url=http://www.carbontax.org/blogarchives/2012/07/06/book-review-the-case-for-a-carbon-tax-by-shi-ling-hsu/ |accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=Hsu>{{cite web |title= The Case for a Carbon Tax |url=http://islandpress.org/ip/books/book/islandpres/C/bo8079222.htm/ |publisher=carbontax.org |accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref>
=== Stern Review 2006 ===
Economist Nicholas Stern also supports putting a price on carbon as explained in his Stern Review. The Stern Review is significant in that it is the largest and most widely known and discussed economic report on climate change of its kind.<ref name="Cairncross_2006-10-30_firstpost">{{cite web | first = Francis | last = Cairncross | title = Time to get Stern on climate change | date = 30 October 2006 | work = The First Post | url = http://www.thefirstpost.co.uk/index.php?menuID=2&subID=1055 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070926221549/http://www.thefirstpost.co.uk/index.php?menuID=2&subID=1055 | archivedate = 26 September 2007 | df = }}</ref> Entitled ''Stern Review on the Economics of Climate Change'', this 700-page report was released for the [[Her Majesty's Government|British government]] on 30 October 2006. In it, Stern discusses the effect of [[global warming]] on the world economy, and states that climate change is the greatest and widest-ranging [[market failure]] ever seen, presenting a unique challenge for economics.<ref name="stern_2006_exec">{{cite web |last=Stern |first=Nicholas |title=Stern Review on The Economics of Climate Change (pre-publication edition). Executive Summary |year=2006 |publisher=HM Treasury |location=London, United Kingdom |url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/sternreview_index.htm |access-date=31 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nCeyEYJr?url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/sternreview_index.htm |archivedate=31 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> According to the Stern Review, without action, the overall costs of climate change will be equivalent to losing at least 5% of global gross domestic product (GDP) each year, now and forever.<ref name="peston-2006">{{cite news | first = Robert | last = Peston | title = Report's stark warning on climate | date=29 October 2006 | work = BBC News | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6096594.stm }}</ref> The Review provides prescriptions including [[environmental taxes]] to minimize the economic and social disruptions. The Stern Review's main conclusion is that the benefits of strong, early action on climate change far outweigh the costs of not acting.<ref name="shortes">{{cite book | first = Stern | last = Nicholas | title = Executive summary (short) | year = 2006 | contribution = Summary of Conclusions | series = Stern Review Report on the Economics of Climate Change (pre-publication edition) | publisher = HM Treasury | location = London, United Kingdom | format = PDF | url = http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/d/CLOSED_SHORT_executive_summary.pdf | access-date = 28 April 2011 }}</ref> Some of the report's main conclusions are:<ref name=stern_2006_exec/>
* The benefits of strong, early action on climate change outweigh the costs. * The scientific evidence points to increasing risks of serious, irreversible impacts from climate change associated with [[Economics of climate change mitigation#Baselines|business-as-usual]] (BAU) paths for emissions. * Climate change threatens the basic elements of life for people around the world – access to water, food production, health, use of land and the environment. * The impacts of climate change are not evenly distributed – the poorest countries and people will suffer earliest and most. And if and when the damages appear it will be too late to reverse the process. Thus we are forced to look a long way ahead. * Emissions have been, and continue to be, driven by economic growth; yet stabilization of [[greenhouse gas]] [[concentration]] in the [[atmosphere]] is feasible and consistent with continued growth. * Establishing a [[carbon price]], through tax, trading or regulation, is an essential foundation for climate change policy. * There is still time to avoid the worst [[Effects of global warming|impacts of climate change]] if strong collective action starts now.<ref name="stern_2006_exec"/>
=== Energy Modeling Forum study 2012 ===
{{main|Fee and dividend#Energy Modeling Forum study 2012}}
In late-2012 the [[Energy Modeling Forum]] (EMF), coordinated by [[Stanford University]], released its EMF{{nnbsp}}29 study titled "The role of border carbon adjustment in unilateral climate policy".<ref name="emf-29-website">{{cite web | title = EMF 29: The role of border carbon adjustment in unilateral climate policy | website = Energy Modeling Forum (EMF) | location = Standford, CA, USA | url = https://emf.stanford.edu/projects/emf-29-role-border-carbon-adjustment-unilateral-climate-policy | access-date = 2016-10-22 }}</ref><ref name="boehringer-etal-2012a"><!-- note: details here based on the recommended citation in the preamble to the document -->{{cite book | last1 = Böhringer | first1 = Christoph | last2 = Rutherford | first2 = Thomas F | last3 = Balistreri | first3 = Edward J | title = The role of border carbon adjustment in unilateral climate policy: Insights from a model-comparison study — Discussion Paper 2012-54 | date = October 2012 | publisher = Harvard Project on Climate Agreements | location = Cambridge, MA, USA | url = http://live.belfercenter.org/files/bohringer_dp54_v3-final.pdf | access-date = 2016-10-22 }}</ref><ref name="boehringer-etal-2012b">{{cite journal | last1 = Böhringer | first1 = Christoph | last2 = Balistreri | first2 = Edward J | last3 = Rutherford | first3 = Thomas F | title = The role of border carbon adjustment in unilateral climate policy: overview of an Energy Modeling Forum study (EMF 29) | date = December 2012 | journal = Energy Economics | volume = 34, Supplement 2 | pages = S97–S110 | doi = 10.1016/j.eneco.2012.10.003 | issn = 0140-9883 }}</ref> It is well understood that unilateral [[climate policy]] can lead to [[Carbon leakage|emissions leakage]]. As one example, trade-exposed emissions-intensive industries may simply relocate to regions with laxer climate protection. A border carbon adjustment (BCA) program can help counter this and related effects. Under such a policy, tariffs are levied on the carbon embodied in imported goods from unregulated trading partners while the original climate protection payments for exported goods are rebated.<ref name="emf-29-website"/> The study finds that the BCA programs evaluated can reduce [[Carbon leakage|emissions leakage]], can yield modest gains in global [[economic efficiency]], and will shift substantial costs from abating [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]] counties to non-abating non-OECD countries.<ref name="boehringer-etal-2012b"/> This last finding is regressive and counter to the equity principles contained in the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|UNFCCC]].<ref name="emf-29-website"/>
=== Regional Economic Models study 2014 ===
A private economic modeling company, Regional Economic Models, Inc (REMI), was commissioned by Citizens' Climate Lobby to conduct an objective analysis of the economic impacts of a revenue neutral carbon fee and dividend in the US. The study found that, if enacted in 2016, by 2036: US {{co2}} emissions would be reduced 50% below 1990 levels; because of the economic stimulus of recycling carbon fee revenue back to households 2.8 million jobs would be added to the American economy; improved air quality would result in 230,000 premature deaths avoided over that time period.<ref name="remi-report-2016">{{cite web | title = REMI Report — The Environmental, Economic and Health Impact of Carbon Fee and Dividend | website = Citizens' Climate Lobby | location = California, USA | url = https://citizensclimatelobby.org/remi-report/ | access-date = September 11, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="nystrom-and-luckow-2014">{{cite book | first1 = Scott | last1 = Nystrom | first2 = Patrick | last2 = Luckow | title = The economic, climate, fiscal, power, and demographic impact of a national fee-and-dividend carbon tax | date = 9 June 2014 | publisher = Regional Economic Models (REMI) and Synapse Energy Economics (Synapse) | location = Washington, DC, USA | url = https://11bup83sxdss1xze1i3lpol4-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/The-Economic-Climate-Fiscal-Power-and-Demographic-Impact-of-a-National-Fee-and-Dividend-Carbon-Tax-6.9.14.pdf | access-date = September 11, 2016 }}</ref>
== Organizational structure == Citizens' Climate Lobby is a network involving its US, international and Canadian head offices, and the dedicated volunteers that comprise the various chapters throughout the United States and Canada and other countries. Marshall Saunders remains the organization's president alongside his wife, Pamela Saunders.<ref name="staff_members">{{cite web |title=Citizens' Climate Lobby Staff |url=https://citizensclimatelobby.org/about-ccl/staff/ |website=citizensclimatelobby.org |accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> Mark Reynolds is the group's executive director.<ref>{{cite web|title= The Thom Hartmann Show, Will America get a Federal Carbon Tax?|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E92QTvlvRmo/|accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref> Cathy Orlando serves as the manager for the Canadian branch of the Citizens' Climate Lobby.<ref name ="CCL_Canada"/>
Regional coordinators in the US regularly communicate with the local group leaders in their geographical region. Aside from the few paid staff members, the organization is run by thousands of volunteers. Often volunteers will initiate a new group by themselves, or with just one or two others, until they find enough other people nearby to formally start a new group. When a new group is started, orientation and training is provided through the respective national office.<ref name="Citizens" />
Citizens' Climate Lobby is coordinated through regular email communication at all levels, monthly international teleconferences and group meetings, weekly international, national or regional group leader calls; national websites; social media communication at different levels.<ref name="Citizens" />
The largest focal point each year is the Annual International Conference in June, which includes meeting with and lobbying as many members of Congress as possible in Washington D.C. Canada's Citizens' Climate Lobby has in the past coordinated its annual meeting and lobbying activities in Ottawa with other organizations but held its first Annual Conference and Lobbying Days in November 2013.
Citizens' Climate Lobby additionally holds a smaller, secondary conference known as the Congressional Education day each November.<ref name="Citizens" />
== Priorities and influence == The work of Citizens' Climate Lobby has an influence at the local and the national scale. At the local scale, Citizens' Climate Lobby brings concerned citizens together as a community to educate themselves and others, including through the media, and to create a voice on climate change to present to locally elected representatives of the federal government. This includes Members of the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] and [[United States Senate|Senators]] in the United States and [[Members of Parliament]] and Senators (appointed) in Canada.<ref name="Citizens" />
Citizens' Climate Lobby believes it is important for members to meet and create a relationship with local representatives as a means of "putting a face" on local chapters and to provide information and state their concerns regarding climate change legislation. When there is an important climate bill being considered in the nation's capital, members of Citizens' Climate Lobby bring it to the attention of their elected representatives and lobby for their support as appropriate. The chapters also act to keep citizens informed about climate legislation and timely actions to take. Monthly local chapter meetings allow members to share information about climate change issues, to plan for upcoming events related to climate change and to provide mutual support.<ref name="Citizens" />
At the national level Citizens' Climate Lobby chapters can directly influence federal legislation via the work completed at the local level. These chapters contribute to a growing network of people across the country who share the same initiative. Together these individuals and groups become a powerful voice that can capture the attention of other citizens and of municipal and federal representatives alike.<ref name="Citizens" />
== Initiatives ==
Citizens' Climate Lobbyists create political will for a sustainable climate and empower others in many ways, including by: * Educating themselves, their friends and people of influence about the science, economics, sociology, business, denial machine, politics, communication, and many other aspects of climate change. They sponsor weekly educational webinars which are nicknamed "Citizens' Climate University (CCU)".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://community.citizensclimatelobby.org/learn/|title=Learn - CCL Community|publisher=}}</ref> * Writing handwritten letters to politicians, especially Members of Congress, Parliament and National Assemblies, and recruiting others to do so. * Lobbying politicians directly in their constituency offices and in the capital cities. * Participating in community events where they engage the public in climate change awareness and actions. * Creating awareness in the media by writing stories, blogs, media releases, letters to the editor, opinion editorials, tweets, status updates, etc., and submitting them to traditional (radio, TV, and newspapers) and 21st century sources (blogs, online magazine and social media). * Developing partnerships, alliances and relationships with a range of groups towards building a broad and diverse base support which will create political will for a sustainable climate<ref name="Citizens" />
== Accomplishments == * The number of local groups roughly doubled each year for many years, from 3 in 2007 to 6 in 2008, to 14 in 2009, to 24 in 2010, to 44 in 2011, to 74 in 2012, to 148 in 2013, to 228 in 2014.<ref name="Citizens" /> In October 2017, there are 450 chapters. * Citizens' Climate Lobby has written a legislative proposal, The Carbon Fee and Dividend Act, introduced by Dr. James Hansen at an Earth Day rally on the National Mall in Washington.<ref name="proposed_legislation" /> * Published Letters to the Editor have grown from 537 in 2012 to 2,253 in 2014, to 3,034 in 2015.<ref name="Citizens" /> * Letters to Members of Congress have grown from 5,547 in 2014, to just over 40,000 in 2016, to 51,920 by October in 2017. * Editorial Board meetings have grown from 24 in 2012 to 52 in 2014. Published Opinion Editorials (Op Eds) have grown from 87 in 2012 to 291 in 2014.<ref name="Citizens" /> * Congressional Meetings have grown from 534 in 2012, to 1,086 in 2014, to 1387 in 2016.<ref name="Citizens" /> * The annual international conference in Washington, D.C. has grown from 175 attendees in 2012, to 367 attendees in 2013, to over 1,300 attendees in 2017.<ref name="2013_conference">{{cite web|title=Citizens Climate Lobby 2013 Conference Report|url=http://citizensclimatelobby.org/ccl-2013-conference-report/|accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref> In 2015, over 800 volunteers participated in 487 meetings with Congressional offices. * Citizen Climate Lobby published an economic report, Building a Green Economy (September 2010) written by CCL member Joseph Robertson.<ref name="Green_Economy_Robertson">{{cite web|title=Building a Green Economy|url=https://www.amazon.com/Building-Green-Economy-Joseph-Robertson/dp/0982649177/|accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref> The report is now used as a source with the media and Members of Congress.
== CCL by country ==
=== Canada ===
Canada's Citizens' Climate Lobby participates in many climate related projects and actions. Some of the initiatives to date include:{{when|date=September 2016}}
* Joining US volunteers at the Annual Conference/Lobbying in Washington, D.C.; to meeting with Members of Congress. * Meeting with Members of Parliament (Canada) and Members of provincial legislative assemblies (MLAs/MPPs/MHAs/MNAs) to discuss carbon fee and dividend policy and other climate issues.<ref name ="CCL_Canada"/> * Working in collaboration with the Climate Action Network Canada to encourage Canada's government to remove fossil fuel subsidies and put a fair price on carbon pollution. * Pushing for a Pan Canada Energy Strategy * Participating in the Parliamentary Petition Project for a sustainable climate. * Developing relationships and strategic partnerships with like-minded groups locally, provincially, nationally and internationally.<ref name ="CCL_Canada"/>
=== Germany ===
In Germany, CCL is known as ''{{lang|de|Bürgerlobby Klimaschutz}}'' and abbreviated {{nowrap|CCL-D}}.<ref name="ccl-d-website">{{cite web | title = Bürgerlobby Klimaschutz — Citizens' Climate Lobby Germany | url = http://de.citizensclimatelobby.org | access-date = 2016-09-23 }}</ref> Like other CCL groups, {{nowrap|CCL-D}} seek a steadily rising and socially equitable price on carbon. However their first focus is on overhauling the [[European Union Emissions Trading System]] (EU{{nbsp}}ETS) as follows:<ref name="ccl-d-position-paper-summary">{{cite book | title = Positionspapier — Kurzfassung | trans-title = Position paper — Summary | language = German | date = 5 May 2016 | publisher = Bürgerlobby Klimaschutz | location = Munich, Germany | url = https://de.citizensclimatelobby.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/5/2015/07/Positionspapier_Kurzfassung.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-21 }}</ref>
* extend the EU{{nbsp}}ETS so that all emissions are covered and modify the annual cap so that 2030 emissions sink by at least 50% relative to 1990 levels * introduce a continuously increasing floor price for {{CO2}} allowances * introduce a [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] compliant border adjustment system to level the playing field between European companies and their global competitors
As long as there is no effective price signal at the [[European Union|EU]] level, {{nowrap|CCL-D}} call for a national [[carbon tax]] for Germany on all {{CO2}} emissions as a transitional measure.
A central theme for {{nowrap|CCL-D}} is that, for an equitable and socially-compatible [[carbon price]], all revenues must be redistributed back to the population on a per-capita basis.
== Connections == Citizens' Climate Lobby is a non-partisan group that develops and maintains relationships with and may coordinate some activities with a broad base of organizations that share similar goals. In 2013, [[Bill McKibben]], founder of [[350.org]],<ref name="350.org">{{cite web|title=350.org|url=http://350.org/|accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref> endorsed CCL by saying "I love working with Citizens' Climate Lobby—their relentless focus on the need for a fee-and-dividend solution is helping drive the debate in precisely the right direction. I'm enormously grateful for their persistence and creativity."<ref name="Citizens" />
==See also== {{Portal|Economics|Environment|Global warming|Social movements|Sustainable Development}} {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[10:10]] – a climate change campaign * [[350.org]] * [[Emissions reduction|Air pollution reduction efforts]] * [[Avoiding Dangerous Climate Change]] – a 2005 conference on the topic * [[Fee and dividend|Carbon fee and dividend]] * [[Carbon price]] * [[Climate change mitigation]] * [[Climate change policy of the United States]] * [[Climate movement]] * [[Climate Solutions Caucus]] * [[Conservation (ethic)]] * [[Economics of global warming]] * [[Environmental movement]] * [[Garnaut Climate Change Review]] * [[Individual and political action on climate change]] * [[List of environmental issues]] * [[Politics of global warming]] * [[Stern Review]] * [[World Energy Outlook]] {{Div col end}} {{Clear}}
