'''''Monthon''''' ({{lang-th|มณฑล}}) were [[Administrative divisions of Thailand|administrative subdivisions of Thailand]] at the beginning of the 20th century. The Thai word ''monthon'' is a translation of the word ''[[mandala]]'' (''{{IAST|maṇḍala}}'', literally "[[Circle (country subdivision)|circle]]"), in its sense of a [[Mandala (Southeast Asian political model)|type of political formation]]. The monthon were created as a part of the ''[[Thesaban|Thesaphiban]]'' ({{lang|th|เทศาภิบาล}}, literally "local government") [[bureaucracy|bureaucratic]] administrative system, introduced by Prince [[Damrong Rajanubhab]] which, together with the monthon, established step-by-step today's present [[Provinces of Thailand|provinces]] (''changwat''), districts (''[[amphoe]]''), and communes (''[[tambon]]'') throughout [[Thailand]]. Each monthon was led by a royal commissioner called ''Thesaphiban'' (เทศาภิบาล), later renamed to ''Samuhathesaphiban'' (สมุหเทศาภิบาล). The system was officially adopted by the 1897 Local Administration Act, after some monthon had been established and administrative details were sorted out.
== History == {{further|Mueang|Southeast Asian political model|Tusi}} Before the ''Thesaphiban'' reforms, the country consisted of partially independent cities called ''[[mueang]]'', some directly subordinate to the capital, some subordinate to larger ''mueang'', or to one or more of the [[tributary state|tributary kingdom]]s. Before the reforms, [[governor]]s inherited their posts from their family lineage, and lived on taxes they collected in their area, a practice formally called [[Farm (revenue leasing)|tax farming]]. These were converted from hereditary governors to appointed governmental posts, as had been done by Chinese [[Yuan dynasty|Yuan]], [[Ming dynasty|Ming]], and [[Qing dynasty|Qing]]-era rulers in first recognizing [[Tusi]] (tribal leaders) as imperial officials, then replacing them with imperial appointees. The arrangement resulted in governors being appointed and paid by the central government, and ''mueang'' developed into [[provinces of Thailand|provinces]]. An essential step in the ending of tax farming was the creation on 3 September 1885 of the [[Royal Thai Survey Department|Royal Survey Department]]. Though its first fruits were not obtained until 1901, the department's [[cadastral survey]]s, i.e., surveys of specific land parcels, made possible the defining of ownership for [[land registration]] and equitable [[taxation]]. The term ''changwat'' (จังหวัด) for the provinces was first used in 1907 for the provinces in Monthon Pattani, and by 1916 had come into general use.
== Resistance to reform == It took till around 1910 to implement the system throughout the country. The main reason for the slow implementation was the lack of suitably educated officials,<ref>{{cite book |title=Twentieth century impressions of Siam |author= W. G. Johnson|editor1-last= Wright|editor1-first= Arnold |editor2-last= Breakspear|editor2-first= Oliver T |year= 2008 |origyear= 1908 |publisher= Lloyds Greater Britain Publishing Co |location=London|page=276|chapter= Education |quote= Siam has progressed so rapidly of late years, and the machinery of Government has been reorganised and perfected so quickly, that it requires all the efforts of the Education Department to produce from its schools the supply of men capable of taking up the posts in the Government service|url=https://archive.org/download/twentiethcentury00wrigrich/twentiethcentury00wrigrich.pdf |accessdate= January 28, 2012}}</ref> but also the resistance of the traditional local leaders, which recalled the 1768–1770 resistance of the monk Chao Phra Faang to [[Thonburi Kingdom#Reestablishment of Siamese Authority|Thonburi reestablishment of Siamese authority]]. In 1902 along both banks of the [[Mekong]], local revolts ({{lang|th-Latn|Prakottakan Phi Bun}} {{lang|th|ปรากฏการณ์ผีบุญ}}) led by charismatic religious leaders called ''holy man'' or {{lang|th-Latn|phi bun}} ({{lang|th|ผีบุญ}}) broke out. The most serious of these was led by east-bank rebel [[Ong Keo]] against French authority in the former Thai tributary [[kingdom of Champasak]]. On the west bank in the area of [[Ubon Ratchathani]], a less-well known former monk and ''phi bun'' headed a [[millenarian]] sect inspired by his [[Apocalypse|apocalyptic prophecies]], which spread [[fear, uncertainty and doubt]] among almost all the peoples along both banks of the river. The Bangkok government put down west bank resistance with little use of force, and cooperated with [[French Indochina]] officials insofar as limiting Thai authority to the west bank, later called [[Isan]]. East bank resistance however had no definitive end and became subsumed into the [[Second Indochina War]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://atcloud.com/stories/38562 |script-title = th:บทความ ปรากฏการณ์ผีบุญ |accessdate = September 21, 2011 |work = blog |publisher = @cloud |language = Thai |quote = เป็นกระทงร้อน มากกว่า 2 ปีพจนานุกรมฉบับราชบัณฑิตยสถาน ให้ความหมายของ ผีบุญ ไว้ว่า ผู้อวดคุณวิเศษว่ามีฤทธิ์ทําได้ต่าง ๆ อย่างผีสางเทวดาให้คนหลงเชื่อ |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100122010745/http://atcloud.com/stories/38562 |archivedate = January 22, 2010 |df = }}</ref><ref name="JSS_062_1e_Murdoch">{{cite journal | last = Murdoch | first =John B|year= 1974|title=The 1901-1902 Holy Man's Rebellion |journal= [[Journal of the Siam Society]]|volume= 62 |issue= 1|publisher= Siam Heritage Trust |url= http://www.siamese-heritage.org/jsspdf/1971/JSS_062_1e_Murdoch_1901to1902HolyMansRebellion.pdf|accessdate= 2 April 2013}}</ref> Far from the Mekong, resistance to reform continued into the 21st century in the [[Southern Thailand insurgency]].
== Further development == In 1915 there were 19 monthons containing 72 provinces. Due to economic problems, several monthon were merged in 1925. Monthon Phetchabun had been dissolved in 1915. Only 14 monthon remained: Ayutthaya, Bangkok (Krung Thep), Chanthaburi, Nakhon Chaisi, Nakhon Ratchasima, Nakhon Sawan, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Pattani, Phayap, Phitsanulok, Phuket, Prachinburi, Ratchaburi, and Udon Thani. In 1932 another four were abolished: Chanthaburi, Nakhon Chaisi, Nakhon Sawan, and Pattani. Finally in 1933 the whole monthon system was abolished by the ''Provincial Administration Act 2476 B.E./A.D. 1933'', part of the changes made after the [[Siamese coup d'état of 1932|coup d'état]], which changed from an absolute to a constitutional monarchy, and the 70 provinces to second-level administrative divisions.
==List of monthons== ===North=== [[Image:Thailand monthon 1915.png|right|thumb|Map of Thailand 1915]]
*'''Phayap''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลพายัพ}}): [[Sanskrit]] Northwest.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.thai-language.com/id/140203|title= พายัพ |editor= Glenn Slayden|format= Dictionary|work= Royal Institute Dictionary|date=1982|publisher= Thai-language.com |accessdate= 2013-09-29|quote=1982 พายัพ /พา-ยับ/ {Sanskrit: วายวฺย ว่า ของวายุ} [นาม] ชื่อทิศตะวันตกเฉียงเหนือ}}</ref> or '''Monthon Lao Chiang''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลลาวเฉียง}}). In 1899, this northwestern monthon was described in Thai as ''monthon fai tawan tok chiang nuea'' ({{lang|th|มณฑลฝ่ายตะวันตกเฉียงเหนือ}}; literally "northwest-side circle"). In 1900, this was shortened to the Sanskrit for "northwest". The actual administrative reform was established gradually between 1907 and 1915, succeeding the previous high commissionership. It covered the northern principalities of former [[Lan Na]], the provinces [[Chiang Mai Province|Chiang Mai]], [[Lamphun Province|Lamphun]], [[Mae Hong Son Province|Mae Hong Son]], [[Lampang Province|Lampang]], [[Chiang Rai Province|Chiang Rai]], [[Nan Province|Nan]], and [[Phrae Province|Phrae]].
*'''Maharat''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลมหาราษฎร์}}): Monthon Maharat was created in 1915, when Monthon Phayap was split into two halves. It covered the eastern part of former Phayap, i.e., the provinces Chiang Rai, Nan, Lampang, and Phrae. *'''Nakhon Sawan''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลนครสวรรค์}}): Monthon Nakhon Sawan was created in 1895, and was thus among the first created. It covered the provinces of [[Nakhon Sawan Province|Nakhon Sawan]], [[Chai Nat Province|Chai Nat]], [[Kamphaeng Phet Province|Kamphaeng Phet]], [[Manorom Province|Manorom]], [[Phayuha Khiri District|Phayuha Khiri]], [[Sankhaburi Province|Sankhaburi]], [[Tak Province|Tak]], [[Uthai Thani Province|Uthai Thani]]. *'''Phitsanulok''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลพิษณุโลก}}): Monthon Phitsanulok was established in 1894. It covered the provinces [[Phitsanulok Province|Phitsanulok]], Phichai, [[Phichit Province|Phichit]], [[Sukhothai Province|Sukhothai]], Sawankhalok. *'''Phetchabun''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลเพชรบูรณ์}}): Monthon Phetchabun was split off from Monthon Nakhon Ratchasima in 1899. It consisted of the two provinces [[Lom Sak Province|Lom Sak]] and [[Phetchabun Province|Phetchabun]], which were later merged. It then became the only monthon covering a single province. It was temporarily included into Monthon Pitsanulok from 1903-1907, before it was finally abolished in 1915 and incorporated into Monthon Phitsanulok.
===Northeast=== *'''Nakhon Ratchasima''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลนครราชสีมา}}): Monthon Nakhon Ratchasima was the first monthon to be created in 1893. It covered the provinces [[Nakhon Ratchasima Province|Nakhon Ratchasima]] (Khorat), [[Buriram Province|Buriram]], [[Chaiyaphum Province|Chaiyaphum]]. In 1899 Monthon Phetchabun was split off from Khorat. *'''Isan''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลอีสาน}}): Monthon Isan was established in 1900. In June 1912 it was split into the two parts, Monthon Roi Et and Monthon Ubon. *'''Roi Et''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลร้อยเอ็จ}}): Monthon Roi Et was split from Monthon Isan in 1912. It contained the provinces [[Roi Et Province|Roi Et]], [[Kalasin Province|Kalasin]], and [[Maha Sarakham Province|Maha Sarakham]]. *'''Ubon''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลอุบล}}) or '''Monthon Laokao''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลลาวกาว}}): Monthon Ubon was split from Monthon Isan in 1912. It included [[Ubon Ratchathani Province|Ubon Ratchathani]], [[Khukhan District|Khukhan]], [[Sisaket Province|Sisaket]], and [[Surin Province|Surin]]. *'''Udon''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลอุดร}}) or '''Monthon Lao Phuan''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลลาวพวน}}): Monthon Udon was established in 1899. It contained the provinces [[Udon Thani Province|Udon Thani]], [[Khon Kaen Province|Khon Kaen]], [[Loei Province|Loei]], [[Nakhon Phanom Province|Nakhon Phanom]], [[Nong Khai Province|Nong Khai]] and [[Sakon Nakhon Province|Sakon Nakhon]].
===South=== *'''Phuket''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลภูเก็จ}}): Monthon Phuket was established in 1898, succeeding a previously established commissionership. It consisted of the provinces [[Phuket Province|Phuket]], Thalang, [[Ranong Province|Ranong]], [[Phang Nga Province|Phang Nga]], Takua Pa, [[Krabi Province|Krabi]], [[Kelantan]], and [[Terengganu]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Malaysian States|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Malay_states.htm#Terengganu|accessdate=13 May 2017}}</ref> In 1909 [[Satun Province|Satun]] was added when most of the area of Monthon Kedah along with Kelantan and Terengganu were ceded to Britain. *'''[[Monthon Chumphon|Chumphon]]''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลชุมพร}}): Monthon Chumphon was established in 1896 consisting of the provinces [[Chumphon Province|Chumphon]], Chaiya, Kanchanadit, and Lang Suan. Chaiya and Kanchanadit were later merged into one province named Chaiya. In 1905 the monthon administration was moved to Ban Don, the center of Chaiya province. Together with the renaming of Chaiya to [[Surat Thani Province|Surat Thani]] the monthon was renamed "Monthon Surat". In 1925 the monthon was incorporated into Monthon Nakhon Si Thammarat. *'''[[Monthon Nakhon Si Thammarat|Nakhon Si Thammarat]]''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลนครศรีธรรมราช}}): Monthon Nakhon Si Thammarat was established in 1896, consisting of the provinces [[Songkhla Province|Songkhla]], [[Nakhon Si Thammarat Province|Nakhon Si Thammarat]], and [[Phattalung Province|Phattalung]]. *'''Pattani''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลปัตตานี}}): Monthon Pattani was created in 1906, and covered the so-called ''Seven Malay Provinces'' [[Pattani Province|Pattani]] (Tani), [[Yala Province|Yala]], Sai Buri, Yaring, Nong Chik, Raman, Ra-ngae. * '''[[Syburi]]''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลไทรบุรี}}): Monthon Syburi was established in 1897. It covered the provinces [[Kedah Province|Kedah]], [[Perlis]]. and [[Satun Province|Satun]]. In 1909 Kedah was ceded to Britain. Satun, as the only remaining province, was added to Monthon Phuket.
===Central=== *'''Krung Thep''' (Bangkok; {{lang-th|มณฑลกรุงเทพ}}): The area around the capital was under the control of the Ministry of Urban Affairs, however a similar administration was established with the Monthon Krung Theb in 1897. It consisted of the provinces [[Bangkok|Phra Nakhon]], [[Thonburi|Thon Buri]], [[Nonthaburi Province|Nonthaburi]], [[Pathumthani Province|Pathum Thani]], Phra Pradaeng (Nakhon Khueankhan), [[Samut Prakan Province|Samut Prakan]], Thanyaburi, Min Buri. Pathum Thani and Thanyaburi later transferred to Monthon Ayutthaya. In 1915 it was renamed ''Krung Thep Phra Maha Nakhon'' (Bangkok metropolis). In 1922 the Ministry of Urban Affairs was dissolved and put under the Ministry of Interior, like all the other monthon. *'''Ayutthaya''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลอยุธยา}}): Monthon Ayutthaya was created in 1893 as '''Monthon Krung Kao''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลกรุงเก่า}}, ''Old Capital Monthon''), consisting of the provinces [[Ayutthaya Province|Ayutthaya]], also called Krung Kao or "old capital", [[Ang Thong Province|Ang Thong]], [[Lopburi Province|Lop Buri]], [[Phrom Buri Province|Phrom Buri]], [[Saraburi Province|Sara Buri]]. *'''Ratchaburi''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลราชบุรี}}): Monthon Ratchaburi was created in 1895 and covered the provinces [[Ratchaburi Province|Ratchaburi]], [[Kanchanaburi Province|Kanchanaburi]], [[Samut Songkhram Province|Samut Songkhram]], [[Phetchaburi Province|Phetchaburi]] and [[Prachuap Khiri Khan Province|Prachuap Khiri Khan]]. *'''Nakhon Chai Si''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลนครไชยศรี}}): Monthon Nakhon Chai Si was established in 1895, consisting of the provinces [[Nakhon Pathom Province|Nakhon Chai Si]], [[Samut Sakhon Province|Samut Sakhon]], and [[Suphanburi Province|Suphan Buri]].
===East=== *'''Prachinburi''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลปราจิณบุรี}}): Monthon Prachinburi was established in 1893, covering the provinces [[Prachinburi Province|Prachin Buri]], [[Chachoengsao Province|Chachoengsao]], [[Nakhon Nayok Province|Nakhon Nayok]], and [[Phanom Sarakham District|Phanom Sarakham]]. *'''Burapha''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลบูรพา}}): Monthon Burapha was established in 1903, and covered the provinces [[Sisophon Province|Sisophon]], [[Battambang Province (Thailand)|Battambang]], [[Phanomsok Province|Phanomsok]], and [[Siamriap Province|Siammarat]], all in modern-day [[Cambodia]]. In 1907 the area was ceded to French Indochina. *'''Chanthaburi''' ({{lang-th|มณฑลจันทบุรี}}): Monthon Chanthaburi was established in 1906, covering the provinces [[Chanthaburi Province|Chanthaburi]], [[Rayong Province|Rayong]], and [[Trat Province|Trat]]. The monthon was created just before the area of monthon Burapha was ceded, and the French returned Trat Province to Thai authority.
==Boriwen== The larger monthon Phayap, Udon Thani, and Isan had an additional administrative level between monthon and provincial administration. Three to five ''[[boriwen]]'' (บริเวณ), each administered by a commissioner (''khaluang boriwen'', ข้าหลวงบริเวณ).

{| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin-right: 0; margin-left: 1em;" |+Years in Review Summary |- !Year !Summiters !Reference(s) |- style="background: red; color: white" |2012 |547 |<ref name="NG - Maxed Out on Everest">{{cite web|url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2013/06/125-everest-maxed-out/jenkins-text |title=Everest Maxed Out |publisher=ngm.nationalgeographic.com|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> |- style="background:#efefef;" |[[Mount Everest in 2013|2013]] |658 |<ref name="alanarnette">{{cite web|url=http://www.alanarnette.com/blog/2013/06/03/everest-2013-season-recap/|title=Everest 2013: Season Recap: Summits, Records and Fights|publisher=alanarnette.com|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> |- |2014 |106 |<ref name="alanarnette2">{{cite web|url=http://www.alanarnette.com/blog/2014/06/09/everest-2014-season-summary-nepal-tragedy/|title=Everest 2014: Season Summary - A Nepal Tragedy|publisher=alanarnette.com|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> |- style="background:#efefef;" |2015 |0 |<ref name="washingtonpost">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/01/12/for-the-first-time-in-42-years-nobody-made-it-to-the-top-of-mount-everest-last-year/ |title= The Washington Post - For the first time in four decades, nobody made it to the top of Mount Everest last year|author= Peter Holley|date=12 January 2016 |publisher=washingtonpost.com|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> |- |2016 |641 | <reF>[http://www.alanarnette.com/blog/2016/12/30/everest-by-the-numbers-2017-edition/]</ref> |} [[File:Mt. Everest from Gokyo Ri November 5, 2012 Cropped.jpg|thumb|Everest from Gokyo Ri, 2012]] [[File:Andreas Breitfuss Mt Everest Summit.jpg|thumb|People on the summit in 2012]] The '''Mount Everest''' climbing season of '''2012''' included several hundred summitings and the highest fatality total since 1996.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international-zeitgeist/mount-everest-records-deadliest-year-in-over-a-decade-a-859533.html|title=Congestion in the Death Zone: The Story Behind another Deadly Year on Everest - SPIEGEL ONLINE - International|last=Germany|first=SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg|website=SPIEGEL ONLINE|access-date=2017-05-30}}</ref> 683 climbers from 34 countries attempted to climb the mountain, and 547 people summited.<ref name="NG - Maxed Out on Everest2">{{cite web|url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2013/06/125-everest-maxed-out/jenkins-text|title=Everest Maxed Out|work=National Geographic|accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref> A record was set in May when 234 climbers summitted on a single day.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-22680192|title=Everest crowds: The world's highest traffic jam|last=Kelly|first=Jon|date=2013-05-28|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-05-30|language=en-GB}}</ref> There were 11 deaths, some of which were attributed to overcrowding near the peak.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/international/zeitgeist/mount-everest-records-deadliest-year-in-over-a-decade-a-859533.html]</reF>
==Mountaineering season== In addition to an increase in mountaineers compared to previous decades, the success rate for expeditions increased.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2013/06/125-everest-maxed-out/jenkins-text|title=Everest Maxed Out|access-date=2017-06-11}}</ref> There was a 56 percent success rate in summit attempts in 2012, compared to 24 percent in 2000. 547 people reached the summit, compared to 72 in 1990 and 145 in 2000.<ref name="NG - Maxed Out on Everest" />
The difficult decisions made during the climbing season were highlighted by the departure of guiding company [[Himex]] from the mountain after concerns about a hanging serac in the Khumbu icefall. Two years later, 16 Nepalese guides were killed when ice broke from the serac and created an avalanche.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/death-and-anger-on-everest|title=Death and Anger on Everest|date=2014-04-21|website=The New Yorker|access-date=2017-06-11}}</ref>
In 2012 [[Montana State University]] conducted a scientific expedition to Everest. The Everest Education Expedition studied the geology of the Everest massif which includes Everest-Nuptse-Lhotse-Khumbutse, and advanced the state of mineralogy, strain, and predicted rock ages. Of interest was the fossil-bearing limestone that crowns Mount Everest, the nature and impact of ice in the region (such as the icefall), and the overall [[stratigraphy]] (including limestone, [[metamorphic rock]]s, [[pelite]]s, and [[quartzite]]s).<ref name="montana.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.montana.edu/everest/about/research.htm|title=Montana State University - Everest Education Expedition - Scientific Research|work=montana.edu|accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref>
In May, [[Tamae Watanabe]] became the oldest woman to reach the summit, at the age of 73. She broke her own record, set in 2002 at the age of 63. The retired office worker lives at the base of Mount Fuji, and had climbed many other peaks including Denali, the Eiger, and Lhotse. She climbed with a group of four, and beat a competing 72-year-old woman who was trying for the same record.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/nepal/9279824/73-year-old-becomes-oldest-woman-to-climb-Mount-Everest.html|title=73-year-old becomes oldest woman to climb Mount Everest|date=21 May 2012|author=Julian Ryall|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref>
The ''[[Guinness Book of World Records]]'' states that 234 climbers summited on one day in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/highest-mountain|title=Guinness - Highest mountain}}</ref> However, it was one of the deadliest seasons since 1996, with 11 climbers dying on Everest in the spring.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/zeitgeist/mount-everest-records-deadliest-year-in-over-a-decade-a-859533.html|title=Congestion in the Death Zone: The Story Behind another Deadly Year on Everest|author=Lukas Eberle|work=Der Spiegel}}</ref>
==Fatalities== The death of Canadian climber [[Shriya Shah-Klorfine]] in May made headlines and fed a debate about whether inexperienced climbers should climb Mount Everest. Issues of overcrowding and unqualified guides were also raised.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/five-myths-about-mount-everest/2014/04/24/9a30ace2-caf5-11e3-a993-b6b5a03db7b4_story.html|title=Five myths about Mount Everest|author=Grayson Schaffer|date=24 April 2014|work=Washington Post|accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="cbc" /> Although Shah-Klorfine did manage to summit, she did not survive the descent.<ref name="cbc">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/exclusive-canadian-everest-victim-used-inexperienced-company-lacked-oxygen-1.1195149|title=Canadian Everest victim used inexperienced company, lacked oxygen|date=14 September 2012|work=CBC|accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.macleans.ca/general/the-lure-and-the-cruelty-of-mount-everest/|title=The lure, and the cruelty, of Mount Everest|author=Barbara Amiel|work=Macleans|accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref> Questions were raised about her lack of previous mountaineering experience, as Everest was reportedly her first mountain climb. The guiding company she employed had reportedly never guided a climber to the summit before.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/society/life/more-details-and-blame-in-the-death-of-canadian-everest-victim/|title=More details, and blame, in the death of Canadian Everest victim - Macleans.ca|date=2012-09-14|work=Macleans.ca|access-date=2017-07-14|language=en-US}}</ref> Other factors involved overcrowding on the mountain,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/save-me-last-words-of-mount-everest-climber-1.1182656|title='Save me' last words of Mount Everest climber|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-06-03|language=en}}</ref> a late summit bid, and insufficient bottled oxygen.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/exclusive-canadian-everest-victim-used-inexperienced-company-lacked-oxygen-1.1195149|title=EXCLUSIVE {{!}} Canadian Everest victim used inexperienced company, lacked oxygen|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-07-14|language=en}}</ref> The company alleges that she ignored instructions to turn around and earlier recommendations to not attempt the climb due to her lack of climbing skills.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/society/life/more-details-and-blame-in-the-death-of-canadian-everest-victim/|title=More details, and blame, in the death of Canadian Everest victim - Macleans.ca|date=2012-09-14|work=Macleans.ca|access-date=2017-06-03|language=en-US}}</ref>
Four people, including Shah-Klorfine, died on Saturday May 19, 2012. Conditions on the mountain were described as overcrowded.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/save-me-last-words-of-mount-everest-climber-1.1182656|title='Save me' last words of Mount Everest climber|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-07-14|language=en}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable collapsible sortable floatleft|" style="font-size: 90%; " |- ! style="text-align:center;" colspan="2"|2012 fatalities |- !Deaths<ref name="HBD-Deaths">{{cite web|title=Deaths - Spring 2012|url=http://www.himalayandatabase.com/2012%20Season%20Lists/2012%20Spring%20A18.html|website=The Himalayan Database|accessdate=31 January 2017}}</ref> !Nation<ref name="HBD-Deaths"/> |- |Ralf Dieter Arnold |{{Flagcountry|Germany}} |- |Juan Jose Polo Carbayo |{{Flagcountry|Spain}} |- |Karsang Namgyal |{{Flagcountry|Nepal}} |- |Ramesh Gulave |{{Flagcountry|India}} |- |Namgyal Tshering |{{Flagcountry|Nepal}} |- |Dawa Tenzing |{{Flagcountry|Nepal}} |- |Wen-Yi Ha |{{Flagcountry|PRC}} |- |Dr. Eberhard Schaaf |{{Flagcountry|Germany}} |- |[[Shriya Shah-Klorfine]] |{{Flagcountry|Canada}} |- |Won-Bin Song |{{Flagcountry|South Korea}} |- |Milan Sedlacek* |{{Flagcountry|Czech Republic}} |- |Temba Sherpa*<ref>[http://www.himalayandatabase.com/2012%20Season%20Lists/2012%20Autumn%20A11.html]</ref> ||{{Flagcountry|Nepal}} |- |colspan="2"|<center>''*Lhotse fatality''</center> |} {{clear}}

{{See also|Index of Jamaica-related articles}} {{double image|right|Flag of Jamaica.svg|220|Coat of Arms of Jamaica.svg|107|The [[Flag of Jamaica]]|The [[Coat of arms of Jamaica]]}} [[Image:LocationJamaica.svg|thumb|The location of [[Jamaica]]]] [[Image:JamaicaOMC.png|thumb|An enlargeable map of [[Jamaica]]]] The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Jamaica: '''[[Jamaica]]''' – [[List of sovereign states|sovereign]] [[island nation]] located on the [[Island of Jamaica]] of the [[Greater Antilles]] [[archipelago]] in the [[Caribbean Sea]].{{cite web|date=July 6, 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/jm.html|title=Jamaica|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} It is {{convert|234|km}} long and {{convert|80|km}} at its widest. It lies about {{convert|145|km}} south of [[Cuba]] and {{convert|190|km}} west of the [[Hispaniola]]. Its [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous]] [[Arawakan languages|Arawakan]]-speaking [[Taíno]] inhabitants named the island ''Xaymaca'', meaning the "Land of Wood and Water", or the "Land of Springs".{{Cite web|url=http://www.uctp.org/VocesIndigena.html |title= Taíno Dictionary |author=The United Confederation of Taíno People |accessdate=2007-10-18|language=Spanish |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071016055722/http://www.uctp.org/VocesIndigena.html |archivedate = 2007-10-16}} Formerly a [[Habsburg Spain|Spanish]] possession known as ''Santiago'', it later became the [[British Empire|British]] [[British West Indies|West Indies]] [[Crown colony]] of Jamaica. It is the third most populous [[English-speaking world|anglophone]] country in the [[Americas]], after the [[United States]] and [[Canada]]. {{TOC limit|limit=2}} == General reference == [[Image:Jamaica-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|An enlargeable basic map of [[Jamaica]]]] * [[International Phonetic Alphabet|Pronunciation]]: * Common English country name: [[Jamaica]] * Official English country name: [[Jamaica]] * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages| ]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states| ]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): [[Jamaica]]n * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[Etymology]]: [[Name of Jamaica]] * [[International rankings of Jamaica]] * [[ISO country codes]]: JM, JAM, 388 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:JM]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.jm]] == Geography of Jamaica == [[Image:Jamaica Topography.png|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Jamaica]]]] [[Geography of Jamaica]] * Jamaica is... ** an [[island]] ** a [[country]] *** an [[island country]] *** a [[nation state]] *** a [[Commonwealth realm]] * Location: ** [[Northern Hemisphere]] and [[Western Hemisphere]] *** [[North America]] (though not on the [[mainland]]) ** [[Atlantic Ocean]] *** [[North Atlantic]] **** [[Caribbean]] ***** [[Antilles]] ****** [[Greater Antilles]] ** [[Time zone]]: [[UTC-05]] ** Extreme points of Jamaica *** High: [[Blue Mountain Peak]] {{convert|2256|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} *** Low: [[Caribbean Sea]] 0 m ** Land boundaries: ''none'' ** Coastline: [[Caribbean Sea]] 1,022 km * [[Population of Jamaica]]: 2,714,000 - UN Estimate [[List of countries by population|137th most populous country]] * * [[Area of Jamaica]]: 10,991 km² - [[List of countries and outlying territories by total area|166th largest country]] * [[:commons:Atlas of Jamaica|Atlas of Jamaica]] === Environment of Jamaica === [[Image:Satellite image of Jamaica in November 2001.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable satellite image of [[Jamaica]]]] * [[Climate of Jamaica]] * [[Renewable energy in Jamaica]] * [[Geology of Jamaica]] * [[Protected areas of Jamaica]] ** [[List of biosphere reserves in Jamaica|Biosphere reserves in Jamaica]] ** [[List of national parks of Jamaica|National parks of Jamaica]] * [[Wildlife of Jamaica]] ** [[Fauna of Jamaica]] *** [[List of birds of Jamaica|Birds of Jamaica]] *** [[List of mammals of Jamaica|Mammals of Jamaica]] * [[Effects of Hurricane Charley in Jamaica]] ==== Natural geographic features of Jamaica ==== * [[List of beaches#Jamaica|Beaches of Jamaica]] * [[List of islands of Jamaica|Islands of Jamaica]] * [[List of lakes in Jamaica|Lakes of Jamaica]] * [[List of mountains of Jamaica|Mountains of Jamaica]] ** [[List of volcanoes in Jamaica|Volcanoes in Jamaica]] * [[List of rivers of Jamaica|Rivers of Jamaica]] ** [[List of waterfalls of Jamaica|Waterfalls of Jamaica]] * [[List of valleys of Jamaica|Valleys of Jamaica]] * [[List of World Heritage Sites in the Americas#Jamaica|World Heritage Sites in Jamaica]] (none) === Regions of Jamaica === [[Regions of Jamaica]] ==== Ecoregions of Jamaica ==== [[List of ecoregions in Jamaica]] * [[Ecoregions in Jamaica]] ==== Administrative divisions of Jamaica ==== [[Administrative divisions of Jamaica]] Administratively, [[Jamaica]] is divided into fourteen [[parish (subnational entity)|parish]]es. '''Robert B. Potter''' (24 February 1950 – 12 April 2014) was a British academic geographer, focussing on urbanisation and development issues in the Caribbean. He was Emeritus Professor at the [[University of Reading]], UK.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.reading.ac.uk/geographyandenvironmentalscience/about/staff/r-b-potter.aspx |title=Professor Emeritus Rob Potter - University of Reading |publisher=Reading.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-05-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140515014931/http://www.reading.ac.uk/geographyandenvironmentalscience/about/staff/r-b-potter.aspx |archivedate=2014-05-15 |df= }}</ref>
==Background== Potter was trained in geography at the University of London in the 1970s (BSc first class, Bedford College 1971; PhD on urban retailing 1974/5). From 1974 he rose through the ranks at [[Royal Holloway]], University of London (initially working at Bedford College, later merged), becoming Professor of Geography and then Head of Department (1994-1999).<ref>https://www.royalholloway.ac.uk/iquad/news/articles/2014/robpotter.aspx</ref> He joined the Department of Geography at the University of Reading in 2003, and later became Head of its School of Human and Environmental Sciences (2008-2012). He battled cancer from 2009, and retired in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Reisz |first=Matthew |url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/news/people/obituaries/rob-potter-1950-2014/2013234.article |title=Rob Potter, 1950-2014 | People |publisher=Times Higher Education |date=2014-05-15 |accessdate=2014-05-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rgs.org/OurWork/Publications/Obituaries.htm |title=Obituaries |publisher=Rgs.org |date= |accessdate=2014-05-26}}</ref>
==Contributions== Potter was a leader in the study of urbanisation trends in developing countries, notably in the Caribbean. He worked on urbanisation, housing and planning, tourism, gender, returning migrants and human aspects of environmental hazards. A later focus was second-generation transnational migration to the Caribbean (Barbados, St Lucia, Trinidad and Tobago).<ref>http://www.rgs.org/NR/rdonlyres/9CD043C5-914C-41A2-BD2C-EE8287FF1301/29783/RobPotterTribute2.pdf Obituary</ref>
Latterly he obtained a Leverhulme Trust Programme Grant, ''Water, Life and Civilisation'', based on the Middle East and North Africa (MENA), writing books and articles on water management in Jordan.
He was a consultant to the Government of [[Barbados]] and the Inter-American Development Bank for the Third National Physical Development Plan for Barbados.
He produced several textbooks on geographies of development and development studies, and founded the journal ''Progress in Development Studies''. A prolific writer he authored 30 books and 250 articles.
==Awards== * Academician of the Academy of Social Sciences * Awarded a DSc, University of Reading, UK * Fellowship, Institute for Advanced Study, Indiana University (2006)
==Publications== * Desai, V. and Potter, R.B. (eds.) 2014. ''The Companion to Development Studies''. 3rd edition. Routledge, London and New York. * Potter, R.B., Conway, D., Evans, R. and Lloyd-Evans, S. 2012. ''Key concepts in development geography''. Sage Publications, London. * Potter, R.B. 2010. ''Urbanisation and planning in the Third World: spatial perceptions and public participation''. Routledge, London, UK, * Conway, D. and Potter, R.B. (eds.) 2009. ''Return Migration of the Next Generations: 21st Century Transnational Mobility''. Ashgate, Farnham UK and Burlington USA. * Potter, R.B., Binns, T., Elliott, J.A. and Smith, D. 2008. ''Geographies of Development: an Introduction to Development Studies.'' Pearson-Prentice Hall, Harlow, London, New York. * Potter, R.B., Lloyd, M. and Jacyno, J. 2007. ''A Social Atlas of Barbados: a cartographic and statistical analysis''. Arawak Publications, Kingston, Jamaica. * Potter, R.B. and Phillips, J. 2006. ''Citizens by Descent: Bajan-Brit Young Return Migrants''. Ashgate, Aldershot and Burlington, USA. * Desai, V. and Potter, R.B. 2006. ''Doing Development Research''. Sage Publications, London, Thousand Oaks and New Delhi. * Colantonio, A. and Potter, R.B. 2006. ''Urban Tourism and Development in the Socialist State: Havana during the 'Special Period'''. Ashgate Publishing Company, Aldershot UK and Burlington USA. * Potter, R.B. Conway, D. and Phillips, J. 2005. ''The Experience of Return Migration: Caribbean Perspectives''. Ashgate Publishing, Aldershot and Brookfield, USA. * Potter, R.B., Barker, D., Conway, D. and Klak, T. 2004. ''The Contemporary Caribbean''. Pearson/Prentice-Hall, London and New York. * Pugh, J. and Potter, R.B. (eds.) 2003. ''Participatory planning in the Caribbean: lessons from practice''. Ashgate, Aldershot. * Lloyd-Evans, S. and Potter, R.B. 2002. ''Gender, ethnicity and the informal sector in Trinidad''. Ashgate, Aldershot. * Potter, R.B., Lloyd, M. and Jacyno, J. 2003. ''A Social Atlas of Barbados: Cartographic and Statistical Analysis'' Arawak Publications: Kingston Jamaica. * Watson, M. and Potter, R.B. 2001. ''Low-Cost Housing in Barbados: Evolution or Social Revolution''? University of the West Indies Press: Barbados, Jamaica, Trinidad and Tobago.\ *Potter, R.B. 2000. ''The Urban Caribbean in an Era of Global Change''. Ashgate: Aldershot. * Potter, R.B. and Lloyd-Evans, S. 1998. ''The City in the Developing World''. Prentice-Hall: London and New York. * Potter, R.B. and D. Conway (eds.) 1997. ''Self-Help Housing, the Poor, and the State in the Caribbean'' . University of Tennessee Press. * Potter, R.B. 1992. ''St. Vincent and the Grenadines (World Bibliographical Series)''. ABC Clio. * Potter, R.B. 1995. ''Low Income Housing And The State In The Eastern Caribbean''. University of West Indies Press. * Potter, R.B. and A.T. Salau. 1990. ''Cities and Development in the Third World''. Mansell. * Potter, R.B and T. Unwin. (eds.) 1989. ''The Geography of Urban-Rural Interaction in Developing Countries''. Routledge. * Potter, R.B. & G. Dann. 1987. ''Barbados (World Bibliographical Series)''. ABC Clio. * Potter, R.B. 1982. ''Urban Retailing System: Location, Cognition and Behaviour''. Gower.
